metadata.title: Nano-sized MoO2 spheres interspersed three-dimensional porous carbon composite as advanced anode for reversible sodium/potassium ion storage

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Electrochimica Acta
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/electacta
Nano-sized MoO2 spheres interspersed three-dimensional porous carbon composite as advanced anode for reversible sodium/potassium ion storage
Shuo Bao a, Shao-hua Luo a, b, c, *, Sheng-xue Yan a, Zhi-yuan Wang a, b, c, **, Qing Wang b, Jian Feng a, Ying-ling Wang a, b, Ting-feng Yi a, b, c
a School of Materials Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, Shenyang, 110819, PR China b School of Resources and Materials, Northeastern University at Qinhuangdao, Qinhuangdao, 066004, PR China c Key Laboratory of Dielectric and Electrolyte Functional Material Hebei Province, Qinhuangdao, PR China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 29 January 2019 Received in revised form 30 March 2019 Accepted 31 March 2019 Available online 1 April 2019
Keywords: MoO2 spheres Three-dimensional porous carbon Composite material Sodium ion batteries Potassium ion batteries
* Corresponding author. School of Materials Scien eastern University, Shenyang, 110819, PR China. ** Corresponding author. School of Materials Scien eastern University, Shenyang, 110819, PR China.
E-mail addresses: tianyanglsh@163.com (S.-h. Luo (Z.-y. Wang).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.electacta.2019.03.216 0013-4686/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Recently, MoO2 has been widely studied as an anode material owing to its high theoretical capacity and stability. In this study, nano-sized MoO2 is successfully fabricated on three-dimensional porous carbon (3DPC) using a simple hydrothermal method followed by calcination. The composite exhibits higher surface area (171.6m2 g 1) than that of bulk MoO2 (81.4m2 g 1). For the first time, the novel MoO2/3DPC composite is tested in both sodium and potassium ion batteries. The MoO2/3DPC composite exhibits improved electrochemical performance than that of bulk MoO2 powder. In Naþ half cells, the specific charge capacity in the first cycle of the MoO2/3DPC composite at 0.1 A g
1 is ~463mAh g 1 and a reversible capacity of ~367mAh g 1 can be maintained after 200 cycles. In Kþ half cells, the initial charge capacity is ~350mAh g 1 at 0.05 A g 1. In addition, a reversible charge capacity of as high as 213mAh g 1
can be maintained after 200 cycles. The synergistic effect of 3DPC and nano-sized MoO2 improves the electrochemical performance. The unique 3D structure of porous carbon can increase the electrical conductivity and alleviate the absolute stress/strain. Results demonstrate that the MoO2/3DPC composite is one of the promising candidates for Naþ/Kþ storage.
© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since 1990s, lithium ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely commercialized by Sony company and have rapidly controlled the market of the secondary battery industry. Recently, lithium has become expensive because of increasing development of electric equipment; therefore, other energy storage systems must be urgently identified to replace LIBs. Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) and potassium ion batteries (KIBs) have drawn considerable attention because of the inexhaustible distribution of sodium and potassium. Moreover, Na and K have similar chemical properties because they are in the same alkaline metal group. Therefore, SIBs and KIBs are
ce and Engineering, North-
ce and Engineering, North-
), zhiyuanwang@neuq.edu.cn
considered promising candidates for next-generation energy storage.
Sodium/potassium ions have larger radii than lithium ions; therefore, conventional anode materials used in LIBs cannot provide satisfactory capacity. Thus, many alternative anode materials with larger interlayer spacing have been investigated, such as SnO2 [1,2], V2O5 [3], a-MoO3 [4,5], and MoS2/C [6]. For example, Zhao et al. [7] reported a sandwich-type G@MoS2-C nanosheets prepared via a novel two-step strategy. The 2D sheet-shaped structure of the material effectively shortened the diffusion length of Naþ, and the composite could deliver 253mAh g 1 reversible capacity even after 4500 cycles at 3 A g 1 current density. A novel carbonaceous composite with MoS2 nanoflowers configured on carbon fibres was also prepared [8]. When the composite was cycled in SIBs, it showed an ultrahigh capacity of 104mAh g 1 at a current density as large as 20 A g 1. Recently, MoO2 has received research attention as anode electrode for SIBs due to its high theoretical capacity, low electrical resistance, and low cost. Despite the inherent advantages, MoO2 usually suffers from substantial volume change during the
insertion/extraction process of alkali ions, leading to a poor cycling performance [9]. Extensive efforts have been made to overcome this defect, and the preparation of MoO2/carbon composite materials has proven to be an effective way. For instance, Jiang et al. [10] synthesized a MoO2/C nanocomposite using a simple hydrothermal method. This composite delivered a charge capacity of 557.2mAh g 1 at 0.1 C in the initial cycle and had a good cycling stability for Na storage. Cui et al. [11] prepared MoO2@C nanoflowers that were tested at 0.1 A g 1 and showed a reversible charge capacity of 172mAh g 1. In the long-term cycling test (1 A g 1, 1000 cycles), a reversible charge capacity of 166mAh g 1 remained. He et al. [12] reported a MoO2-C composite with MoO2 nanosheets embedded in carbon matrix. The charge capacity vs Na/Naþ after 100 cycles was ~367mAh g 1. Huang et al. [13] synthesized a MoO2 nanoparticlesanchored graphene oxide (GO), and the material exhibited a reversible charge capacity of 345mAh g 1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 A g 1. These studies suggest that building homogeneous composites containing MoO2 and carbon at a nanoscale can considerably enhance the cycling stability of electrodes.
Many types of carbon materials, such as hard carbon [14], GO [15], porous carbon [16] and carbon nanofiber [17], have been reported as anode electrodes for SIBs and LIBs. These materials can effectively facilitate the insertion/extraction of sodium ions [18]. However, most carbonaceous materials cannot provide sufficient capacity in Na half cells, particularly in high-rate tests. Moreover, the electrochemical performance of carbonaceous anodes for SIBs strongly depends on their morphology and pore structure. Recently, three-dimensional porous carbon (3DPC) has attracted considerable attention because of its unique network structure that can effectively accelerate alkali ions diffusion. 3DPC also provides sufficient electrode/electrolyte interfaces that can mitigate volume changes. Carbonaceous materials with 3D structure can deliver excellent electrochemical performance in LieO2 batteries [19,20], and LieS batteries [21]. These composites are promising candidates for alkali ion storage. Qin et al. [22] reported 3D porous graphene networks that were embedded with ultra-small SnSb nanoparticles. The authors suggested that the 3D structure enhanced electron conductivity and offered excess interfacial sodium storage. Wang et al. [23] fabricated a boron-doped 3D porous carbon network using a double-template method. When tested in SIBs, the reversible charge capacity of the material vs Naþ/Na at 0.1 A g 1 after 100 cycles was ~200mAh g 1. Even when the material was cycled at a high current density of 5 A g 1, its reversible capacity reached up to 189mAh g 1. Thus, 3DPC can be used as a superior matrix for hosting active materials.
MoO2 and 3DPC have inherent advantages for alkali ion storage; therefore, a novel composite with MoO2 spheres anchored on 3DPC was successfully developed herein using a simple hydrothermal method. For the first time, the MoO2/3DPC composite was used as an anode electrode in SIBs and KIBs. Owing to the unique 3D nanostructure that provided high surface area and high-speed ions pathway, the MoO2/3DPC composite exhibited improved electrochemical performance than the bulk MoO2 powder in Naþ and Kþ half cells. The as-prepared MoO2/3DPC composite can be a promising candidate for Naþ and Kþ storage.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of 3DPC matrix
sections.text:
3DPC was obtained using a simple template method. First, 2.5 g citric acid (C6H8O7, Aladdin) and 20.7 g sodium chloride (NaCl, Aladdin) were dissolved into 70 ml deionized water and stirred for 10 h. The solution was frozen to solid in a refrigerator overnight. Then, the frozen sample was freeze-dried in vacuum to sublimate
water and heated at 600 C for 2 h under the protection of ArþH2 gas (2:1). After annealing, the obtained powder was washed and filtered several times to remove NaCl template. Finally, the powder was dried at 80 C for 8 h to obtain 3DPC.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of MoO2/3DPC composite
sections.text: The MoO2/3DPC composite was obtained using a simple hydrothermal method, followed by calcination. First, 40mg 3DPC matrix was dispersed into 60ml deionized water via ultrasonication and HCl was added into the suspension to obtain an acidic environment (pH 2). Then, 1.6 g ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24$4H2O, Aladdin) and 0.176-g ascorbic acid (C6H8O6, Aladdin) were separately added into the suspension. The suspension was stirred for 2 h and transferred into a hydrothermal reactor. After heating at 180 C for 15 h, the obtained precursor powder was washed and dried at 80 C overnight. Then, the precursor powder was calcined at 400 C for 3 h under the protection of Ar. After annealing to room temperature, the MoO2/3DPC composite was successfully prepared. For comparison, pure MoO2 powder was also synthesized under the same condition. Fig. 1 illustrates the preparation procedure of the MoO2/3DPC composite.

sections.heading: 2.3. Materials characterizations
sections.text: The XRD patterns of the materials were collected using X-ray diffraction (Rigaku) within the 2q range of 10 e90 at 4 min 1. The morphology and microstructure were observed using scanning electron microscope (SEM, ZEISS SUPRA55) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20), respectively. The surface area and pore structure were estimated using nitrogen adsorption isotherms curves (SSA-4300, China). Raman spectra were obtained from Raman spectrometer (HORIBA LabRAM HR Evolution). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, HCT-2) was performed to evaluate the fraction of 3DPC by heating the material to 600 C in air. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurement (XPS, THERMO ESCALAB 250XI) was employed to analyse the oxidation states of the elements.

sections.heading: 2.4. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text: To prepare the anode electrode, 80-wt% MoO2/3DPC, 10-wt% acetylene black and 10-wt% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF dissolved in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidine (NMP) in a 1:20 ratio) were mixed into homogeneous slurry and coated onto a copper foil. The electrode was punched into circular pieces with a loading mass of ~1mg cm 2. For SIBs, the anode electrodes, Na discs (Aladdin) and Glass fibre (Whatman GF/D) were assembled into CR2032 cointype half cells. The electrolyte was 1M NaClO4 (Aladdin) solution containing ethylene carbonate (EC), diethyl carbonate (DEC) and fluorinated ethylene carbonate (FEC) (VEC:VDEC:VFEC¼ 1:1:0.05). For KIBs, the electrolyte was a 0.8M KPF6 solution containing EC and diethyl carbonate (DEC) (vEC:vDEC ¼ 1:1). Galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles were collected using a LAND battery testing system (CT2001A) between 0.01 and 3 V. Cyclic voltammograms and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) curves were obtained via an electrochemical workstation (Solartron 1260þ 1287, UK) from 0.01 to 3 V at 0.1 mV s 1 for both of Naþ and Kþ half cells.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
XRD patterns of the bulk MoO2 powder, MoO2/3DPC and the corresponding standard PDF card are shown in Fig. 2(a). The crystalline phases of the two samples can be ascribed to monoclinic
MoO2 (JCPDS:86-0135) with space group of P21/c [24]. The XRD patterns reveal no visible impurity peaks, implying the high
crystallinity of the samples. No obvious amorphous peaks corresponding to carbon networks can be found from the XRD patterns
of the MoO2/3DPC composite, which could be attributed to the low carbon content of the sample.
Thermogravimetric analysis was employed to calculate themass fraction of 3DPC in the composite, as shown in Fig. 2(b). The sample was annealed from room temperature to 600 C at 10 C min 1 in air to oxidise the carbon to CO2 and the MoO2 to MoO3. The slight decreased mass before 200 C can be ascribed to the volatilization of the absorbedmoisture. When the temperature reaches to 305 C, the MoO2 and 3DPC start to oxidise. The rapid mass loss process between 355 C and 375 C is because of the intense oxidation of 3DPC. Subsequently, the oxidation of 3DPC gradually stops, leading to a decreasing trend of the slope from 375 C to 450 C. The slight increase of mass until 600 C is attributed to the continuous oxidation of MoO2, resulting in the residual mass fraction of MoO3 to be 84.3%. The result is in good agreement with the TGA curve of bare MoO2 sample, as shown in Fig. S1(a). Based on the final fraction of MoO3, the original MoO2 content is calculated as 74.9%. The thermogravimetric analysis is consistent with the XRD results.
The bulk MoO2 powder, 3DPC and MoO2/3DPC composite were further analysed via Raman spectroscopy. The curves are shown in Fig. 2(c). From the Raman spectra of MoO2/3DPC, five characteristic peaks are observed, representing O¼M¼O wagging (280 cm 1), OeMeO bend (340 cm 1), OeMeO stretch (660 cm 1), M¼O stretch (818 cm 1, Ag, ys) and M¼O (990 cm 1, Ag, yas) stretch, respectively [10,25]. Simultaneously, D band (1365 cm 1) and G (1580 cm 1) band can be observed in the Raman spectra. The characteristic peaks of MoO2 and 3DPC co-exist in the Raman spectra of MoO2/3DPC composite, thus implying that MoO2/3DPC composite has been successfully prepared. The intensity ratio of ID/ IG is ~0.85, demonstrating a relatively high disordered extend of the carbon, which is beneficial for the composite to be used as anode electrode [26,27].
N2 adsorption and desorption measurement was employed to analyse the surface area and pore size distribution of MoO2/3DPC, as shown in Fig. 2(d). The specific surface area of MoO2/3DPC composite is 171.6m2 g 1 after calculation, which is much higher than that of the bulk MoO2 powder (81.4m2 g 1, Fig. S2). Besides
the surface area, the pore size of MoO2/3DPC (0.87 cm3 g 1) significantly improved compared with the bulk MoO2 powder (0.45 cm3 g 1, Fig. S2). Results confirm that the surface area and pore volume could be largely increased by the 3DPC matrix. The development of surface area and pore size can promote the distribution of alkali ions and tolerate the volume change of MoO2 particles during the insertion/extraction of alkali ions. Therefore, the MoO2/3DPC composite is expected to deliver better electrochemical performance.
The morphologies of MoO2 powder, 3DPC matrix and MoO2/ 3DPC composite are shown in Fig. 3(a, b, c). The pristine MoO2 particles (Fig. 3(a)) shows spherical shape with the average size of ~200 nm. The particles aggregate together, which would lead to poor alkali ions storage properties. Fig. 3(b) reveals that the carbon network exhibits 3D porous shape and the average diameter of carbon cages is ~500 nm. The 3D morphology of the carbon matrix is attributed to the preparation process, in which the cubic NaCl particles gathered together during crystallisation and porous morphology retained after washing. The final product after hydrothermal reaction is exhibited in Fig. 3(c). The spherical MoO2 particles are homogeneously anchored on 3DPC matrix and retain their original morphologies and size.
TEM and STEM-EDS measurements are performed to further understand the microstructure of the MoO2/3DPC composite, as shown in Fig. 3(d, e, f). Fig. 3(d) shows the overall morphology of the composite. Spherical MoO2 particles with a size of ~200 nm distribute homogeneously upon the 3DPC, which coincides with the SEM result. Furthermore, STEM-EDS mapping is conducted to investigate the distribution and composition of C, Mo and O, as shown in the inset of Fig. 3(d). EDS mappings show that carbon clearly depicts the outline of 3DPC, whereas Mo and O distribute on their inherent positions. HRTEM images of a single MoO2 particle are shown in Fig. 3(e and f). Highly ordered lattice fringes can be observed. The spacing between adjacent lattices is ~0.34 nm, matching well with the ( 111) plane of MoO2. From the SEM and TEM results, it is concluded that spherical MoO2 particles with good crystallisation are successfully prepared on the 3DPC and the
image and EDS mappings of the overall morphology of MoO2/3DPC composite; (e, f)
MoO2/3DPC is expected to deliver satisfactory electrochemical performance in Na/K ions storage.
The valence states of the elements in MoO2/3DPC composite were analysed via XPS measurement, as shown in Fig. 4. XPS survey spectrum (Fig. 4(a)) clearly shows that the as-prepared MoO2/3DPC composite mainly comprises Mo, C and O. The survey spectrum presents six characteristic peaks of MoO2, including Mo 4p, Mo 4s, Mo 3d, Mo 3p3/2, Mo 3p1/2 and O 1s, which locate at ~39.5, ~67, ~233, ~400, ~415 and ~531 eV, respectively. Mo 3d peak, C 1s peak and O 1s peak are further studied via high-solution XPS. The highsolution spectrum of Mo (Fig. 4(b)) can be fitted into two couples. Peaks at 232 eV (3d3/2) and 228.9 eV (3d5/2) can be attributed to Mo4þ, whereas those at 235 eV (3d3/2) and 231.5 eV (3d5/2) can be attributed to Mo6þ. These peaks were caused by slight surface oxidation of MoO2 [13,28,29]. Fig. 3(c) illustrates the XPS spectra of C 1s, which can be divided into three peaks locating at 283.9, 285.2 and 288 eV, respectively. The strongest peak at 283.9 eV represents CeC bond, whereas the other relatively weak peaks are associated with CeO and C¼O bonds, respectively [30]. The O 1s XPS profile in Fig. 4(d) is related to MoeO, CeO, C]O bonds. The strongest peak at 529.8 eV corresponds to the oxygen species of MoO2 and the two smaller peaks indicate that residual oxygen groups bond with carbon in 3DPC.
Electrochemical properties of the as-prepared MoO2, 3DPC and MoO2/3DPC composite as anode materials in SIBs were tested via galvanostatic dischargeecharge and cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements between 0.01 and 3 V. Fig. 5(a) displays the five initial CV curves of the MoO2/3DPC composite at 0.1mV s 1. The first cycle and subsequent cycles show significant differences. A wide reduction peak at ~1.1 V appeared in the first round and then disappeared in the subsequent scan. This phenomenon is
Fig. 4. XPS and high-resolution spectra of MoO2/3DPC
associated with the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film, leading to irreversible capacity loss [31,32]. In the following cycles, the CV curves are highly overlapped, demonstrating the stable insertion/extraction reaction of Naþ and highly reversible nature of the MoO2/3DPC composite. Figs. S2(a and b) illustrate the CV curves of MoO2 and 3DPC in Naþ half cells, respectively. As shown in Fig. S2(a), the intensity of the reduction peaks continuously decrease, indicating the poor cycling performance of bulk MoO2. A reduction peak at ~1.1 V can be observed in Fig. S2(b), which corresponds to the irreversible capacity loss. In the subsequent cycles, 3DPC exhibits excellent cycling stability. Thus, the cycling performance of MoO2/3DPC is greatly enhanced by 3DPC matrix.
Fig. 5(b) illustrates the dischargeecharge profiles of MoO2/3DPC composite at 0.1 A g 1. The coulombic efficiency of the first cycle is as low as ~47% (987mAh g 1 for discharge, 463mAh g 1 for charge), because massive sodium salt are deposited on the surface of 3DPC and promotes the formation of SEI film, leading to large irreversible capacity of the electrode [33e36]. The residual oxygencontaining groups in 3DPC (evidenced by XPS results) can also lead to irreversible capacity loss [37]. The discharge/charge profiles of MoO2 and 3DPC vs Naþ/Na are exhibited in Figs. S2(c and d). The initial coulombic efficiencies are calculated to be 73.6% and 24.7%, respectively. The maximum capacity of the composite is much higher than the theoretical capacity of MoO2 (838mAh g 1), which could be attributed to the following factors: (1) Reversible reaction between sodium and functional groups on the 3DPC surface such as CeH and CeOH; (2) Formation of the SEI film which traps some sodium ions in MoO2 lattice; (3) According to the sodium insertion mechanism of MoO2 (4Naþþ4e þMoO242Na2OþMo), partial metallic Mo possibly alloys with Naþ, which provides extra capacity
(a. survey spectrum; b. Mo 3d; c. C 1s; d. O 1s.).
[24,29,38,39]. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the MoO2/3DPC shows excellent cycling stability in the subsequent cycles and maintains a specific charge capacity of ~367mAh g 1 after 200 cycles, which is much higher than those of the MoO2 powder (~120mAh g 1) and 3DPC (~240mAh g 1) electrodes. The coulombic efficiency dramatically reaches up to ~100% in the following cycles, matching well with the CV curves. Particularly, the capacity of 3DPC continuously increases, which is normally attributed to the activation of the material [40]. Fig. 5(d) displays the rate performance of MoO2, 3DPC and MoO2/3DPC composite. The MoO2/3DPC composite exhibits obviously higher charge capacity than the bulk MoO2 and 3DPC at all current densities. The enhanced cycling performance as well as the rate capability of MoO2/3DPC composite is related to the 3D porous structure of the carbon matrix with high specific surface area, which offers sufficient contact between electrode and electrolyte, reduces the volume change during cycling and provides extra sites for energy storage [41]. Significantly, the MoO2/3DPC composite retains a reversible charge capacity of ~235mAh g 1 after 500 rounds in a high-rate test (1 A g 1), demonstrating an outstanding cycling stability for sodium ions storage. The improved
cycling performance could be ascribed to the synergistic effect of MoO2 and 3DPC.
When the MoO2/3DPC composite was tested as anode electrode in Kþ half cells, it also exhibited enhanced electrochemical performance compared to the bulk MoO2 and 3DPC. The corresponding electrochemical testing results are shown in Fig. 6. For CV measurement (Fig. 6(a)), the curves are similar with the results vs Na/ Naþ and an irreversible peak can be seen at ~0.7 V, which is associated with the capacity loss in the initial cycle (Fig. 6(b)). The peak formed because of the SEI film that was generated on the surface of 3DPC during Kþ insertion process. The strong peak at 0.01 V represents the deposition of Kþ. As the reaction proceeds, the irreversible peak disappears and the curves almost overlapped, indicating an excellent cyclic stability of the MoO2/3DPC composite in Kþ half cells. CV curves in Figs. S3(a and b) further illustrate that the improved cycling stability benefits from the 3DPC matrix.
Typical galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles of the MoO2/ 3DPC composite are shown in Fig. 6(b). The coulombic efficiency of MoO2/3DPC was ~44.9% in the initial cycle, whereas those of MoO2 and 3DPC are 71.8% and 35.1% (Fig. S3c and Fig. S3d). The relatively
low coulombic efficiency of the composite is caused by the inevitable formation of SEI film, matching well with the above CV results. During the galvanostatic tests in Fig. 6(c), it can be noted that the capacities of MoO2/3DPC composite are much higher than that of bulk MoO2 and 3DPC. Among all the samples, the MoO2/3DPC electrode delivers the highest reversible charge capacities of ~213mAh g 1 after 200 cycles. The bulk MoO2 electrode exhibits fast capacity fading and low reversible charge capacity of ~110mAh g 1. The MoO2/3DPC composite also delivers higher discharge/ charge capacity at all current densities (Fig. 6(d)). The improvement of cycling performance of MoO2/3DPC composite should be attributed to the synergistic effect betweenMoO2 and 3DPC. During the insertion/extraction process of Kþ, the 3D structure is quite beneficial for the growth of SEI film and prevents it from fracturing, thus improving the electrochemical performance of the composite [42]. In the long-term cyclic measurement at 0.5 A g 1 (Fig. 6(e)), the MoO2/3DPC composite retains a reversible charge capacity of ~95mAh g 1, demonstrating excellent cycling performance among all the samples. Thus, the MoO2/3DPC composite exhibits superior electrochemical performance in SIBs and KIBs. The SEM images of
MoO2/3DPC composite after 200 cycles in Naþ half cells and Kþ half cells (Fig. S4) show that the material retains its original microstructure. Recent advanced anode materials for SIBs and KIBs are listed in Tables S2 and S3 in Supplementary Material, which shows that the MoO2/3DPC composite exhibits comparable electrochemical performance to the reported anodes.
EIS measurement was performed to further understand the electrochemical properties of the MoO2/3DPC composite before and after 200 cycles at a constant current in Naþ half cells and Kþ
half cells, respectively (Fig. 7). Each Nyquist plot has a depressed semicircle and a linear tail. The equivalent electric circuits are exhibited in the inset in Fig. 7. The depressed semicircle in high frequency represents the transfer resistance between electrode and electrolyte (Rct), whereas the straight line represents the diffusion impedance of alkali ions [43,44]. The corresponding simulated data of the EIS results are listed in Table 1. The diameter of the semicircle slightly increases after 200 cycles in both SIBs and KIBs, indicating the continuous formation of SEI film during the alkali ion insertion/ extraction process.
For comparison, Figs. S5(a and b) display the electrochemical
impedance spectra of the bulk MoO2, 3DPC and MoO2/3DPC before cycling in Naþ and Kþ half cells and the simulated data of the EIS results are listed in Table S1. It is obvious that the charge-transfer resistance (Rct) value of MoO2/3DPC composite is much smaller than that of MoO2, indicating that the unique 3D porous structure has effectively improved the electrical conductivity and electrochemical reaction kinetics. Moreover, EIS is performed to further study the diffusion coefficient of Naþ and Kþ. The relationship between eZ’ and u 1/2 for MoO2 and MoO2/3DPC in both Naþ and Kþ half cells in low frequency region is shown in Figs. S5(c and d) and the corresponding discussion is introduced in the supplementary materials. The results confirm that the 3DPC matrix provides high ion-diffusion coefficient and facilitates the interfacial electron transport [45].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: Herein, we have successfully synthesized a novel MoO2/3DPC composite with nano-sized MoO2 spheres directly grown on threedimensional porous carbon matrix. The nano-sized MoO2 spheres and the unique 3D porous-structured carbon matrix synergistically enhance the electrochemical performance of the composite for Naþ and Kþ storage. The composite in SIBs deliver the initial charge capacity of ~463mAh g 1 and remains constant at 367mAh g 1 after 200 cycles at 0.1 A g 1. In KIBs, the composite shows a charge capacity of ~344mAh g 1 in the first cycle and exhibits a high reversible charge capacity of 213mAh g 1. Thus, the as-prepared MoO2/3DPC composite is quite suitable for the next-generation secondary batteries and it would be one of the promising candidates for Naþ and Kþ storage.

The enhanced cycling performance as well as the rate capability of MoO2/3DPC composite is related to the 3D porous structure of the carbon matrix with high specific surface area, which offers sufficient contact between electrode and electrolyte, reduces the volume change during cycling and provides extra sites for energy storage [41].

During the insertion/extraction process of Kþ, the 3D structure is quite beneficial for the growth of SEI film and prevents it from fracturing, thus improving the electrochemical performance of the composite [42].

The depressed semicircle in high frequency represents the transfer resistance between electrode and electrolyte (Rct), whereas the straight line represents the diffusion impedance of alkali ions [43,44].

The depressed semicircle in high frequency represents the transfer resistance between electrode and electrolyte (Rct), whereas the straight line represents the diffusion impedance of alkali ions [43,44].

metadata.abstractText: Recently, MoO2 has been widely studied as an anode material owing to its high theoretical capacity and stability. In this study, nano-sized MoO2 is successfully fabricated on three-dimensional porous carbon (3DPC) using a simple hydrothermal method followed by calcination. The composite exhibits higher surface area (171.6m2 g 1) than that of bulk MoO2 (81.4m2 g 1). For the first time, the novel MoO2/3DPC composite is tested in both sodium and potassium ion batteries. The MoO2/3DPC composite exhibits improved electrochemical performance than that of bulk MoO2 powder. In Naþ half cells, the specific charge capacity in the first cycle of the MoO2/3DPC composite at 0.1 A g 1 is ~463mAh g 1 and a reversible capacity of ~367mAh g 1 can be maintained after 200 cycles. In Kþ half cells, the initial charge capacity is ~350mAh g 1 at 0.05 A g 1. In addition, a reversible charge capacity of as high as 213mAh g 1 can be maintained after 200 cycles. The synergistic effect of 3DPC and nano-sized MoO2 improves the electrochemical performance. The unique 3D structure of porous carbon can increase the electrical conductivity and alleviate the absolute stress/strain. Results demonstrate that the MoO2/3DPC composite is one of the promising candidates for Naþ/Kþ storage. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
